00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserAutoStrings.pl - Force String() to accept any string.
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This file allows you to force String() to accept ANY string as a
00024 legal value.  (It will add the string to the context if it isn't
00025 already defined.)
00026 
00027 To accomplish this, put the lines
00028 
00029     loadMacros("parserAutoStrings.pl");
00030     AutoStrings();
00031 
00032 at the beginning of your problem file.  (You can also pass AutoStrings
00033 a context pointer if you wish to alter context other than the current
00034 one.)
00035 
00036 There is also a routine to help make strings easier to predefine.
00037 For example:
00038 
00039     loadMacros("parserAutoStrings.pl");
00040     DefineStrings("string1","string2");
00041 
00042 would define two new strings (string1 and string2).  You can pass
00043 a context reference as the first argument to add strings to that
00044 context rather than the active one.
00045 
00046 =cut
00047 
00048 sub _parserAutoStrings_init {}
00049 
00050 ######################################################################
00051 
00052 sub AutoStrings {(shift || Value->context)->{value}{"String()"} = "parser::AutoStrings"};
00053 
00054 sub DefineStrings {
00055   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : Value->context);
00056   foreach my $x (@_)
00057     {$context->strings->add($x=>{}) unless defined $context->{strings}{$x}}
00058 }
00059 
00060 ######################################################################
00061 
00062 package parser::AutoStrings;
00063 our @ISA = ("Value::String");
00064 
00065 sub new {
00066   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00067   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00068   my $x = join('',@_);
00069   $context->strings->add($x=>{}) unless defined $context->{strings}{$x};
00070   $self->SUPER::new($x);
00071 }
00072 
00073 ######################################################################

00075 1;
